key_points: Colin Powell, a four-star General and former Secretary of State, passed away due to COVID-19 complications at the age of 84.
Tributes poured in from President Joe Biden, former President Barack Obama, former President George W. Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney, and Secretary of State Anthony Blinken.
Donald Trump's response to Powell's death was to criticize him for endorsing Trump's Democratic opponents and for mistakes made regarding Iraq.
Republicans aligned with Trump mostly remained silent or issued brief statements, avoiding strong praise for Powell.
Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell was among the few Republicans who made effusive remarks about Powell.
Experts claim Trump's approach has changed the way political figures' deaths are mourned, politicizing the mourning process.
Republican political strategist Mac Stipanovich criticized Trump-aligned Republicans for their silence on Powell's death.
Senators Ted Cruz and Tom Cotton, as well as Rep. Matt Gaetz, issued short messages of condolence.
Political figures' deaths and funerals, which used to be unifying events, have become more politicized in recent years.
The article discusses how partisan divisions affect reactions to the deaths of prominent political figures, noting a shift in how these events are commemorated.
spokespersons: Larry Jacobs (Head of the Political Science Department, University of Minnesota)
